abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the Taunsa
            Barrage Emergency Rehabilitation and Modernization Project
            are to take urgent steps to prevent the failure of the
            Taunsa Barrage, which provides irrigation for two million
            acres, in addition to drinking water to several million
            farmers in the rural areas of Southern Punjab; and to
            prepare for similar steps with respect to other existing
            barrages in Punjab. In view of potential environmental
            adversity during construction works, this environmental
            impact assessment provides mitigation measures in compliance
            with the Bank's operational directives on the
            environment, the project having been classified as category
            B. This category is justified, since environmental impacts
            will be localized over immediate project areas and
            agricultural lands will be avoided at the construction
            stage. Contractors shall comply with specific contract
            requirements and with the social framework agreement
            precautionary clauses. In addition, retrogression downstream
            and pulsating hydraulic jumps shall be in compliance with
            technically sound and economical designs of the secondary
            weir, as will all other aspects of construction, and/or
            engineering design. Construction wastes will be disposed of
            at selected sites, and is the responsibility of the
            contractor as defined in relevant contracts. Soil erosion
            will be controlled, and the terrain should stabilize
            accordingly. Oil spills, lubricants, and hazardous materials
            will be stored in covered tanks, to be disposed of per
            standard international regulations. Drainage systems will be
            regularly inspected to avoid any possible sedimentation or
            obstruction. Embankments or concrete walls will be installed
            around the construction perimeter to secure construction
            sites. Regular discharges and water flows will be regularly
            controlled to avoid potential surface and water
            contamination, while construction surfaces, and materials
            should be covered to avoid air pollution. To mitigate noise
            disturbances, working schedules will be limited to daytime
            working hours. Inspections will be conducted by wildlife,
            forest, and fisheries officials to ensure environmental
            protection of sites or enforce legislation as needed. The
            report also addresses social issues, including tribal
            issues, particularly on the uses of canals and aquatic life.
